21717757.review:
I'll say after finishing Eden* that it was quite a ride. 

Very much a novel, just with some voice acting and very nice visuals going along with it. No real choices to make during the game, so won't get that kind of gameplay out of it.

But I can say it was very much worth getting. For a summary that talks about the planet's final love story, it certainly delivers on that front. You know how it is going to end, but it takes nothing away from the power of the story. It's one of those times when you know how things will turn out and it's all the more impactful because of it. Finding out how things ended up like this and the journey the main characters went through.

In terms of story and characters Eden* just delievers. I also appreciated the strong art and visuals. It is just japanese voices and english subtitles, but the voice acting is top notch. A nice touch as well that you do get to see lips moving as the characters talk so it really does feel like you are watching this story from up close. I don't think the story would have been as good if the MC wasn't as complete a character as the rest of the cast and you had dialogue options popping up. Everything just worked for the sake of the story.

Took me about 12 hours to get through it. Might take others a bit less time, but if you are letting all the characters speak their voiced lines then it will take a good while. Definitely worth what I paid for such a strong story. And got to me enough that I wanted to write up something about it.

It is a story that will leave a bittersweet feeling behind, but if that doesn't bother people then I wholly recommend it.

[spoiler](Well, forgive my poor English anyway)[/spoiler]

[h1]In the beginning[/h1]
I bought it in the IndieGala Charity pack,and I also purchased one as a present to my friend [spoiler]for the belief of Eden*,Sion and Minori[/spoiler],as now I'm reliving the game, I will say some of my feelings.
Eden* is my favorite one in the VNs I have played/experienced, although I didn't go over as many as some VN fans. And Sion is the person I love best, in my own heart. My portrait is Sion's back shadow.

[h1]About Eden*[/h1]
Talking about Eden* in Minori's history, it is another pinnacle production after having a great success in [i]ef - a fairy tale of the two[/i], at that time they have really much money to produce a same-level production.
Whatever the resolution of the game, artwork of background&character,movable emotion CGs,almost every element in the game, has reached a height that few opponent can compete with.

[h1]My understandings in detail[/h1]
The artwork of the game is mainly presented by ちこたむ&KIMちー, not ななお なる in former productions of Minori, but the artwork is still exquisite.[spoiler]Almost every frame of this game can be screenshot and set as your desktop image,better performace with the magnify tools like Waifu2x in high resolution screens.[/spoiler]
[spoiler]Try playing it in fullscreen, fantastic experience.[/spoiler]
Comparing with others, Eden* is not a long story, won't cost you too much time finishing all of the story.But all main character have their enough full characteristic in this story.
The illustration is also different from other VNs, with lots of static illustrations of the event, while many others use set painting plus background. Showing more storytelling attribute in the whole story.

The opening is not the production of Makoto Shinkai, but can say it from his disciple, with lots of style of Makoto Shinkai.
You may not find such a shocking PV among many VNs, when you see the glass shatter and the ruin collapse into pieces, background turn into grass at the moment Ryou and Sion hold their hand, and the surrondings suddenly change into wide angle view of  blue sea and sky with the running of Sion.

The script, or the story by IURO, has a big framework,but much simple and obvious [spoiler]or straight[/spoiler] story-line. But you can see it pays a lot of work in completing the characteristic in every main character in the game, like Ryou, Sion ,Elica and so on.
Some might say the end of word is not an important part of the whole setting of the story,but I think that it is not the whole and most important part of the story, but the element of it. The crucial part should be the story between the characters in the story.
Or, simply saying, a love story in a dying planet.[i]They were only two, on the planet[/i], of course the setting of the end of the word is the foil of the atmosphere and melody of this beautiful and ,well, tearjerker story.
Although the story doesn't have many choices for you to decide, but it is coherent. In other words, it is not an adventure game,seems more like a long story that let you to read.

The OP and bgm is from Tenmon,or Shiragawa Atusi,which also produce the bgm of ef, although many bgm can be seemed as the modified tone of the theme song Little explorer, but when you play the game, you can find the whole story is more colorful and lively with these soundtracks. Though the character voice and the artwork of the game is better than many opponents,but the soundtrack is the assistance of letting the game more than touching your heart.

[h1]My feeling of Eden*[/h1]
In the opening of the game I see Sion running on the grass with Ryou at her side, and standing on the small hill, with [i]To the new world[/i], it gives me a strong feeling of getting rid of constraint of the institution, walking freely on the new world with Ryou.
I see the ending of the story,but I still feel so sad when it comes to the farewell in the setting sun.
In the epilogue of the story, looking at the happy and warm, sweet story finally comes to the end, making me awfully sad, even if I have known that the end is unavoidable, I can't stop the sad feeling spread out of the screen, into my heart.
Though I have forgotten how to cry for many years, but looking at the end of the story,and [i]Desire[/i] like the final detainment, describing the reluctant of the world and love with Ryou from Sion,I feel so sad that I can't say any word.

[h1]Conclution[/h1]
Though Eden* was released in 2009, debarked steam in 2015,but it is still can be one of the best Japanese VNs ever.
So, if you haven't experience the charm of Japanese galgame ,and/or don't like too many choices in the game, Eden* would be your good choice.
Thank you for reading.
お休み,シオン

10/10 recommend

——update 2016.11.26

I would like to nominate eden* for The Steam Award: I didn't cry, just a grain of sand in my eye.

I'm going over this story once again, it still touches me, and it worth the prize.

Maybe eden* is not as magical like The Stanley Parable, Civilization VI or many other games, but, well, there's not any other game or VN can replace the place in my mind, that's all.

21657110.review:
我玩过的galgame并不多，可能我的评论会有点片面，但eden*这款游戏是我玩过的对我印象最深刻的galgame了。
这是一款游戏时长说不上长，也没有什么选项的游戏，比起那些有选项，推妹子的galgame来说，这款游戏更像是一部小说。一部有音乐，有画面的电子小说。
小说最重要的莫过于剧情。而eden*的剧情可以说是非常的精彩。没有多余的描述，也没有什么特别的福利。无论是前期与诗音的相遇，那种有些许紧张的逃离，还是后期那些有点平淡的日常。这些剧情为我们刻画了一个又一个活的人物。尽管早就看到了最后的结局，那个顺理成章的结局。但是结局真正到来的时候，诗音的告别，还是令我泪下。
[spoiler]做不了煎鸡蛋了，对不起……
让你迁就我的任性，对不起……
不能陪伴你到最后……对不起……		
这样的告别，使我不得不回想起游戏之前与诗音的点点滴滴，那些已经成为过去的过去。而这使得整个剧情，得到了一个升华。所有的过去那些微不足道的日常，因为诗音的离去而离去。而只有失去的东西，才能愈发感觉到她的可贵吧。 
或许，这个算不上是喜剧的结局，也许就是最好的结局吧。[/spoiler]
至于这个游戏的其他方面，比如bgm或者是画面。制作也都算精良。其在衬托剧情方面，我没有感受到违和的地方。而且在许多地方，bgm和画面，也使得剧情的表述更加有力。
总而言之，但就我本人而言，这是我力荐的一部作品。
（这是我的第一篇评测，若有不足或不对的地方，还请大家多多包涵啊）

四年前，她对着我这陌生人问了一句：你难道喜欢动漫？我回到：这还用问吗？她淡淡说了句哦就离开了。二个月后，她说：那天漫展你会来吗？我说：会来的，等我。后来那天我闭馆最后两个小时来了，她看了我一眼，一言不发的跟朋友走掉了。之后发了个短信给我：竟然你来了，那我也该走了。
      三年前，她问我：我明天还能见到你吗。我没有回答，只是我摸了摸她的头笑着。半年后，她冲着我背后就是一拳，然后又从背后抱着我，然后说道不准看我脸，不然我揍死你。为什么半年都不联系我，为什么？那天晚上，我背后的衣服都能感受到了一阵湿透的感觉。
      两年前，在烟花表演准备结束的时候，她跟我说：你看那里的烟花好美。我转了头看了一下，她的嘴唇便悄悄的在我的面颊下压了下去，然后抱着通红的脸跑走了。
      一年前，在一次偶然的晚会上，她穿着一身服装来[spoiler](不要深究)[/spoiler]，我半蹲着说到：公主大人，你真美，我能成为你的王子吗。她说，如果你能做到的话，你可以试试的。
      今天，我出现在她家门口，我俩对视着，她说：一年前你说你要成为我什么的？我笑着说：我还记得。

About eden*:

Seriously, did I play the same game as everyone else? I feel like I have been rick rolled, like this game was a gag and I'm waiting for the punchline. Don't get me wrong, I have a heart and can find romance in games wonderful if told right. To the Moon is a great modern example. 

This game game just never captivated me for a second, and when I saw the credits role I laughed out loud, not believing that is the end.

So in this game world, there are only 2 men, the protagonist and one other guy just to show that this isn't about young girls and their love for cold, strong killers. Every single other character is an incredibly immature (in appearance and behavior) girl who all fall in love with the protagonist at some point (yep, every single girl) at some point. 

The protagonist is a 2 dimensional killer, who says the most outrageous and plain weird things (your face is too big) but is turned into a "human" again by the 100 year old in a 12 year old body.... yeah, I'm open... Lolita was a great book/ movie, but it had a point. It felt like this whole premise of this game was just a males hot fantasy about innocent, naive, defenseless young girls (yeah yeah she's 100... keep telling yourself that.)

The content is painfully immature, I am a lover of literature, and I must admit this is my first true visual novel, and first dip into Manga and I am shocked at the banality and two-dimensionality story telling found here. It was as if it was written by a young 20 year old male, with no higher education, who has got stuck in his high school fantasies of hooking up with the 1st grade newbies. 

That this visual novel comes so highly recommend by a variety of sources brings me to wonder and awe at the other "Delights"that are out there for me never to read.

8 hours of my life that I will never get back. I can not in any way recommend this game, and advise anyone who is over his or her teenage years to step clear away from this (Harry Potter The Philosophers Stone by comparison would appear like one of Dostoevsky more complicated pieces). 1/10

21273661.review:
Ok, I'm going to be honest here. Eden* is one of the best stories I've ever experienced in any medium. It is an absolute masterpiece, and that's not hyperbole. If you're looking for a brilliantly-crafted story that has tragedy, intelligent characters, meaningful dialogs, romance done right, and bittersweetness all around, look no further. It also has one of the most interesting fictional characters I've seen (Sion), and her interactions with the main protagonist (Ryou) are fascinating.

One more thing to note. Much like the movie "Full Metal Jacket", Eden* is split into two distinct halves, and in my opinion, the second half is where the VN actually starts. The first half is moderately interesting, but fairly dry, and for me mostly exists as necessary backstory and character introduction. The second half is where Sion really shines and the VN properly begins.

That being said, $20 is a steal for a story you'll never forget.

100 years old girl sends humanity into space, stays behind on this supposedly dying planet.
Well, i don't think i'd trust her spaceships...

Pros:
+ Short, yet amazing story.
+ Good art, music and voice overs.
+ No issues with the translation/localization.
+ No choices, so just sit back and enjoy a good tearjerker.
+ Sion is legal.

Cons:
- Does not include tissues.
- Simple 2-word chars. Badass MC. Helpless genius. Ninja maid. Dojikko reporter. etc.
- Untapped potential. Story doesn't go deep into the planet's issues. Maybe to avoid pseudo-science.
- Usual japanese writing. Requires fair amount of suspension of disbelief. Dialogues often go nowhere. etc.

21177604.review:
前言：Eden* They were only two,on the planet——那是地球最后的恋爱故事。
中二社巅峰时期的作品之一，质量自然棒到不行，心中永远的神作。不入简直没道理！[spoiler] （中二社：拉我一把QAQ）[/spoiler]
[h1]一：上架steam的相关[/h1]
09年的旧作，morir这个略有点排外的厂商上架steam着实奇怪[spoiler] （中二社果然缺钱得不行←_←）[/spoiler]， steam版几乎没做任何变化，基本就是把当年PC零售版搬了过来，仅仅把文本译成英文，遗憾的是没有保留日文原版文本，[spoiler] 当然18X也没有←_←[/spoiler]，所幸英文翻译质量不差，其他的话就没任何变化了[spoiler] （图标都还是当年的低分辨率版，明明是偷懒吧！）[/spoiler]，同时分辨率也没有提升，当年首创的1024×640现在则是缩在桌面一角还挺可怜的>_<
[h1]二：汉化相关[/h1]
英文版并不能用之前诗音教会的日文版汉化补丁，目前汉化可用的方法只有用日文版文件去覆盖然后汉化也就是传统的覆盖法（以后如果汉化补丁重新编辑那么应该就可以用汉化补丁了不过重编辑概率略低）覆盖法大意就是就是拷贝你可以玩的盗版去覆盖steam版（一般在某盘\STEAM\STEAMAPP\COMMOM\EDEN中）覆盖后将文件中eden_Launcher.exe改名eden_en.exe即可 （steamer的传统技能嘛或），者度娘盘链接:http://pan.baidu.com/s/1kUyCYkJ 密码: rjem （这个是从贴吧转载的，时间太久了找不到原始发布者了实在抱歉）下好后覆盖即可，实测可以从steam内启动可以检测到运行并计时，但是不能F12截图什么的。。[spoiler] （steam内启动是没有特典的←_←,想要特典的话在文件夹内的图标启动，启动的金钥匙是eden pm X64.reg（64位系统）或者eden pm X86.reg（32位系统）注册表文件怎么用自己脑补吧）[/spoiler]
其实还可以对照文本一句一句看嘛，提高提高英语水平←_←
[h1]三：关于eden的简介[/h1]
minori[spoiler] （也就是中二社）[/spoiler]的第六作，在ef取得成功后中二社意气奋发腰包鼓鼓几乎不吝惜成本的新作，制作团队有了些许变化，与前作相比显得温润了些，游戏全程无选项无互动其实更像是电影，当然无论是新海诚风格的几乎是动画电影级的OP，还是数量相当不少且非常精致的cg（人物的眼睛会眨而且嘴也会动哟），还是异常好听氛围感极强的音乐，都能体现出这部游戏相当的诚意，PS天门也有参与音乐制作，新海诚加天门的组合是不是有点秒5的感觉呢。。
（另外这作的op虽说新海诚没直接参与，但中二社前四作op都由新海诚制作，员工主创受指点影响颇多，这作op的主力更是挺长期来接受新海诚调教的结城辰所以风格上非常相像，而且后面的特别感谢中似乎也提到了新海诚）
[h1]四：关于eden的个人感受[/h1]（这段是我的闲言碎语大可不看啦。。）
看似是一个宏大的末世题材，在如此一个写实向的架空世界观下，演绎的却是一个纯粹简单到有些单薄的故事。故事基本可以分成两段，前段是男主与sion的相遇，描述的是sion在洋馆中生活遇到的人和事，描述中间穿插着男主的回忆，剧情发展很快，有些悬疑成分（雾）情节相对紧张，整体基本是由下向上的。后段逃出洋馆后则是大段的日常，以及迎来一切的 终结，剧情相对宽松些，整体则是由上向下。限于篇幅，其实本作故事是略显单薄的，与短短的篇幅相对的则是本作想传达的东西却是极多且异常抽象，通完全篇会有一种明明知道了一点它想表达的却无法描述无从说起的感觉，而背景方面虽然有着看似宏大的世界观，但世界的毁灭只是其中微小的剧情点缀。故事中对世界观的提及极少，提及之处无不为了剧情发展，感觉上这个世界观就显得十分缺乏支撑了，给人感觉就是，故事发展和其背景有奇怪的距离感，也许这就是渺小人类在面对这种不具象化大事件时的真实感受。与背景故事相反的，对人物的刻画则要细致的多，本作出场的主要人物不多，约莫7个。。男主与sion当然是肯定的主角，但在每段旅程，遇到的每个角色却都有着自己的故事，性格与选择。在一个确定的未来下，每个人都在前进着，抉择着。使故事有着一种奇妙的真实感，这大概就是与背景距离感的最大由来吧。但在故事的发展下，却又时时提醒着那稍有距离的背景的存在，一个飘渺一个真实，才是我觉得剧情上的最大奇妙之处。最后在营造情绪上，本作的手段也是无可挑剔，明明sion的死一开始就成为了预定的结局，但在一切的崩塌时，在累积了那么多幸福时，在sion说对不起时，却依然会难以抑制眼眶漫溢的泪水，所谓哀而不伤，但惆怅却会如喉咙的鱼刺长久的留在心中。
关于动画化。。我觉得游戏的背景缺乏支撑，想传达的东西太多，想传递的情感太复杂，大概是它至今没能动画化的主要原因
其实整个故事我觉得也可以看做是对圣经中人类早期的另类演绎，从伊甸园到末日洪水确实有几分对照。当然这是我瞎想的。

从许多年前第一次接触eden时的震撼，到三年前第一次为了一部作品痛哭，再到今天终于感到满足地默默流泪。看了许多遍的故事，随着年龄和经历的增长，每一遍都能发现新的细节和感动。这是我心目中无法替代的唯一的作品，独一无二的温柔的作品，承载着我感动伊始与成长的作品。感谢minori，感谢在我懵懂无知的时候，遇到了你。

漫长的现实过去了，而更加漫长的梦才刚刚开始。

晚安，诗音。

————————————————————————————————————————————

从2016年的“我没哭，这里面有洋葱”，到2017年的“世界已冷酷至极，让我们携手前行”。不论时间如何变化，eden在我心中始终留有一席之地。

21035696.review:
Pues hacía tiempo que le seguía la pista a esta novela gráfica pero nunca encontraba el momento de hincarle el diente.

Tengo que decir que me ha sorprendido gratamente, superando en mucho mis expectativas.

El juego nos pone en la situación de un mundo al borde de la extinción debido a una inminente catástrofe natural de naturaleza desconocida.

Por suerte, gracias a la felix Sion se ha podido llevar a cabo la construcción de unas enormes naves utilizadas para evacuar a toda la humanidad hacia el espacio.

Para que nos entendamos los seres conocidos como felix son humanos creados artificialmente con unas grandes capacidades mentales y cuya vida es muy superior a la de un humano común, aunque por desgracia no tienen la habilidad de poder reproducirse.

En esta historia nos ponemos en la piel de Haruna, un joven militar que es destinado a una base secreta donde se encuentra Sion y su asistenta personal.

No entraré más en el tema narrativo porque sería hacer spoilers, así que os lo dejo para vosotros, pero os recomiendo sin duda que le deis una oportunidad.

A nivel gráfico y artístico es muy bello. Me atrevería a decir que tiene cierto aire a anime. Todos los personajes y escenarios están recreados con mucho cariño, de eso no hay duda.

Uno de los apartados que me han sorprendido muchísimo es el sonoro. Normalmente no le doy demasiada importancia a este aspecto en una novela gráfica, pero es que en este caso es brutal.

Cabe destacar que todas las conversaciones están dobladas en japonés, lo cual a mí particularmente me encanta.

La duración es realmente larga, yo creía que duraría como un juego cualquiera de la saga Sakura (4 o 5 horas), pero que va, dura mucho más.

Un puntazo a su favor es que a media novela hay una especie de video de opening increíble, que nada tiene que envidiar a ningún opening de cualquier serie de Anime actual.

Si tuviera que ponerle una pega es que no viene traducido al español, pero este tema ya es muy habitual y repetitivo en las novelas gráficas de steam.

Hay que decir que la versión de Steam viene censurada, aunque si buscáis un poquito por ahí podéis encontrar el parche que habilita la versión hentai (te da la opción de ver 4 escenas íntegras, de unos 30 minutos cada una de puro hentai, una con cada chica de la novela gráfica).

El juego también cuenta, como en la mayoría de novelas gráficas, con su galería de imágenes donde encontraremos absolutamente todas las escenas del juego.

Creo que no me dejo nada por comentar. Atrevería a decir que es de las mejores novelas gráficas que he leído por el momento. Muy profunda, larga, que te da que pensar y con ese toque hentai extra y completamente opcional por si te gustan esas cosas.

Le doy un 9/10.

20837223.review:
No expense was spared for the making of the visuals in this VN. The dynamic camera angles (as opposed to the generic character-sprites most VN's employ), the subtle animations, and the general aesthetic quality makes it worth a read. The music was well done and certainly reinforced the scenes properly. 
The author made the storyline flow properly, and at a decent pace. There are no routes, and no choices to be made, as this is a kinetic novel. For me, it felt like a short VN, but for others it might be considered quite a long read time (to be fair, it took me 8 hours to finish).
Overall, a well-crafted read. It squeezes some tears out of me, and I had a blast with this touching little story.

20798090.review:
この星の空に、最後の軌跡を――
这是我人生中接触的第一个GAL，是还在很久之前，看到这个MAD，感到非常的感人，很想去玩一玩，之后由于各种原因，在玩了很多很多GAL以后，依然没有玩这部我第一个接触的GAL。最后选择了入正然后推。
+1：
1.唯美的剧情。
2.09年的水平来讲，优美的画风。
3.应景好听的BGM。
4.作为一部GAL ,居然全篇没有一个选项也没有18X内容  我也是惊了。
-1：
1.对于现在来说，CG的分辨率有些低了。
2.过于凄美的结局，虽然成就了一个好的剧本，但同时也让玩家很难受。
总结：好评，虽然多年过去了，这部作品已经淡出众新宅的视线了，但是我依然不会忘记，也不会后悔买了这部作品。
感想的话，刚推完就来写评测的我，或许能扯出一大堆，不过这于后来人的观看并没有什么好处，所以我就只说一句好了
       愿为你的双翼，幻化成风。
       还有，
       晚安，Sion。

20660100.review:
This visual novel, truly is a masterpeice by every single definition of the word.

I have absolutely nothing to generally dislike about this. 

From beginning to end, it's definitely a tear-jerker and really shows just how tragic, emotional, and beautiful the world can be. 

I'm not gonna give much away cause you should read this story for yourself. 

But trust me when I say if you're big on drama, tragedy and romance, and a whole lot of emotional feels, this is definitely a visual novel you're never gonna forget anytime soon.  

The character's are colorful, the visuals are breathtaking, the music is very fitting for each scene and the story is incredible. 

So for those who are looking for a good VN to pass the time, I'd highly recommend this. 

From beginning to end, It'll leave you in a state of amazement. 

Good work to all of those involved with eden*. I absolutely loved it.

20466557.review:
An unusually long kinetic novel (no choices/only one ending) featuring full Japanese voice-over.

I was hesitating to play it because the character art is uninspiring. There are chlichés like oversized breasts, a cute army girl and a cute housemaiden. Part of me was afraid a cute magical cat-girl would appear next but thankfully I was spared this. Luckily the protagonist is not some silly perverted fool tripping into his own personal harem he has secretly dreamed for but a rather cold-hearted war veteran, and there are a couple other characters of that sort that you wouldn't necessarily expect in your more ordinary anime.

Despite some initial bumps and doubts the game is rather profound and thoughtful and has a better world and story to tell than most other KNs/VNs I have played. Their unoriginal exterior and cliché-like introductions aside the characters were likeable and quite well written and had more depth than meets the eye. The game features a pretty interesting pre-apocalyptic sci-fi scenario that has you experience the final phases of mankind fleeing earth due to a bright red star that appeared in the sky and is said to destroy it. It's featuring some genuine sci-fi elements but isn't dwelling on the technical terms of it as much, it's more about the people and how they handle it all. This and the extensively designed background art (particularily skies and clouds) remind me fondly of the Makoto Shinkai animes that I had seen many years back.

The music deserves some mentioning too; there is plenty of it, it fits the situations nicely and is memorable. I intentionally stopped progressing at times just so I could listen to it more. It features contemplating, sad and upbeat tunes and I wasn't surprised to see that other players were wondering if it was available separately (it isn't in the West afaik, but there is a playlist in the main menu and I guess one can try YouTube or sorts).

I don't think I would've touched it anytime soon if not for the "overwhelmingly oositive" Steam reviews. Thanks to them I put my initial doubts aside and it didn't took me long before I liked it, wanted to see how the story works out, had it touch parts of my heart in several ways and realized that this game is one of the better, higher-value kinetic novels to be found. It raised my bar of expectations towards any other KNs/VNs I will be playing in the future.

20343184.review:
Ah minori.  A galge publisher which I will forever remember by IP blocking all non-Japanese visitors and blame all of us gaijin as responsible for their own country tightening laws regarding erotic games.  How does a game from a publisher like that get an official English translation and got put on Steam is beyond my imagination.

Of course, you all know this is Steam, thus there is absolutely no conventional erotic content in this visual novel.  Forgive me being too lazy to search the internet on whether the actual sex scene got cut for the English release, or was it nonexistent in the original version.  It is irrelevant, because a sex scene in eden*’s story and the mood would be an intrusion, rather than enhancement, and I’m glad that there is none for me to see.

Although far from being a bad vn compare to rest of the genre on Steam, I don’t feel eden* is worth of the $20 asking price.  Gorgeous background CGs coupled with dubious character sprites/portraits of inconsistent style; nicely tuned soundtrack but eclipsed by mediocre voice acting… I can’t pin down what exactly went wrong in the production phase… but something definitely was amiss for such swing of quality in different departments.

Story of eden* is largely a fairytale-ish romance.  (And by “romance” I don’t just mean a love story, but rather a tale of emotion and human nature.)  Background setting: The world’s scientists somehow are convinced that the world will end in about 100 years.  World war then broke out; half of human population died, and the rest formed a unified government and started to build spaceships.  The plan is successful; nearly everybody on Earth got evacuated in the end, and the story really begins on one couple who chose to remain on Earth to live together and eventually faces the inevitable.

Of course, there would be a few more to the story than that which I would not spoil.  The plot does introduce a few more elements to aspire intrigue and perhaps the readers’ tear… but when the time comes, the ending is largely predictable.  I know it’s beside the point and focus, but the vn never tried to explain what exactly is the nature of this “Armageddon” event, and the story doesn’t elaborate on it, deliberately I shall say, which is irritating even more.

So in the end, I feel the story couldn’t leave a positive impact.  It is partly due to the premise of the story is built too much on a hypothetical and fantasy world setting that is far too removed from current reality.  Or maybe I’m just not into love stories about people who know their life would soon end.  It is fine, though, like not all people enjoy horror game/movies and not all like the science fiction genre.

In conclusion, if you dig for a story like this, then you can safely ignore everything I wrote above.  Otherwise I would advise caution, because in the end the experience which this vn brings might very likely not worth the money—and more importantly, the time—you spend reading.

20317444.review:
[i]The final love story on a dying planet.[/i]
Великолепная ВН от разработчиков Wind: A Breath of Heart и Ef: A Fairy Tale of the Two, Minori. Рисовка и стиль точь-в-точь, это радует. Чутка о сюжете, действие происходит в далеком будущем, огромный сгусток энергии, названный «Планета Хаоса», внезапно появляется возле Марса. Этот сгусток пагубно воздействует на Землю. Люди планируют покинуть Землю, чтобы избежать вымирания. У них есть два варианта. Один из них – сформировать Единое Планетарное Правительство. Второй – изобрести технологии, позволяющие жить в открытом космосе. Он называется «План Феликса».
Сюжет затягивает, читается ВН на одном дыхание. Теперь о плюсах и минусах.
Плюсы:
+Сюжет (отличный)
+Рисовка задников (в своем стиле, все очень круто)
+Няшки
+Рисовка персонажей (чувствуется рука Такеши Морики)
+Музыкальное сопровождение (музыка приятная, моментами захватывает)
+Анимация (лицевая анимация персонажей, мелочь, а приятно)
+Озвучка (персонажи полностью озвучены, приятные сейю)
*+Карточки (вполне приличные фоны, смайлы и отличный значок)
Минусы:
-Продолжительность (довольно-таки короткая)
-Отсутствие концовок (не очень большое минус, но хотелось бы чутка вариации)
-Обрезанная версия (вырезан контент 18+)
*-Ачивки (их нету)

* - чисто мои придирки :3

Советую всем любителям ВН, возможно своих денег она не стоит (около 500 руб.), но по скидке взять можно) Не пожалеете)

10из10.

20060704.review:
Eden, this is one of the best romance visual novels I've seen and enjoyed so far, it wasn't much of a fan service (which, was perfectly my taste, except for maya's part) but it mainly relies on it's story plot, normally visual novels would go with a steady story about love in different ways, not complete romance but with comedy and ecchi. Eden was different, in a lot of ways, it has emotions, it shows us how horrible humanity is, it shows us how would the world rot and it shows us how hope still exists in the darkest ways. 
    I've never gotten so addicted to reading a visual novel for 6 straight hours, slide by slide, munching on each and every word... Eden has reminded us of a lot of things, Ryou Haruna, the main character of Eden was a boy who had been given birth in a village on a certain mountain that gathered people that did not want to evacuate to space, eventually they began to fight back to the army since they were capturing them and evacuating to space, ofcourse a lot of them had gone "missing". After a certain while, one day a felix that had escaped from the No.703 Facility escaped to the mountain, her name was Natsume, who eventually became like a sister for Ryou, people started disappearing more and often, at the end even Ryou's' parents, the whole mountain was left with Nastume and Ryou, they had enjoyed the time, but it wasn't long. The No.703 facility staffs had traced her down and had forcibly taken her from Ryou, giving him ultimate despair and made him join the army, to see his sister again. A world where you can make an innocent child who just wants his sister that was going to die within a year, kill people, and by that I meant a lot of people, Ryou had stepped his way up the military and did everything he could, basically killing everything he can to reach Natsume, even his emotions, even his memories for Natsume, at the end all she did was left a shadow in Ryou's heart to keep fighting, but for no reason since she's already dead after a year she was captured back (felix's end of life span). In reality people keep hurting each and other every day, they take, they gain, but they lose as well, no one has ever thought of stopping, they hadn't, they couldn't, and that's how monsters were created, monsters to the society, but horribly sad.
    Sion was another case, her very existence were a disgrace for humanity, the sadness she gave me was a kind that couldn't be expressed by tears, but rather, a smile that couldn't explain human emotions, it was sad, but also breaking my mind. Sion reminded us of the balance in the world, you take, someone gains, you enjoy, someone suffers, you live, someone dies, but the world isn't completely balanced as well, humans have broken it, they took away freedom to continue living, but they didn't give happiness, there were those who had happily evacuated to space, but there were also those who wanted to stay on earth no matter what comes next. I'll get straight to the point now, Sion was created for humanity's survival, she had led the evacuation project for 100 years, right when she finishes it, she wanted freedom, she wanted to try things on earth, try things for life, but the united government had taken that away, they wanted to keep her alive and show her off as hope, she had worked on for 100 years straight, no complaints, yet she couldn't enjoy freedom in her last few months of life. At the end, Sion did escape with Ryou, the government had to announce they found Sion dead in an accident for test, but Sion's death did not bring sorrow only, it also brought hope, it empowered people they have to keep moving on, to carry on the death wish of their savior...
    Things have been completely ridiculous, the war that started before humanity was destroyed almost destroyed themselves, they never realise technology made life comforting but could also destroy humanity on another hand... I once thought about it but never made a fuss, now that I read Eden, it made me understood how selfish governments are, they wanted stable economics, society, but not people's happiness. Eden's definitely the game where you want to be sad, but as you feel sorrow, you might feel that you couldn't cry for it. (seems like at the end, Ryou had also broken down due to Sion's death)

20018711.review:
Do not think of this as a game. Think of it as a novel. There are no choices to make. It's simply a linear story.

That said, it's a very interesting story and it's very well-told. The characters are nicely complex and nuanced, as is the overall plot. What I find most interesting is the way it puts a spin on the traditional concept of "moe" (which I usually abhor).

This is a love story, but it's not at all smutty. I can count the number of moments that come anywhere close to the usual fanservice that plagues anime and the like on the fingers of one hand.

The story got me to cry, but only because I let it. I went into this looking for an emotional binge of sorts, and that's exactly what I got. I also got a few more profound things to think about--not life-changing, but very interesting.

For what it is, I give it an A-. :)

I have to say I was disappointed by this VN. It often felt like the dialogue was way too drawn out. I just couldn't care about the characters at all. It had some sweet moments and a few laughs but the drama itself fell flat. I feel like they could have cut out half of the dialogue and nothing would have been lost.

They built an interesting world but never really explored it at all. 

Also a lot of people say that this VN doesn't benefit from the H scenes that the 18+ version offers. I would have to agree, but they didn't sufficiently edit the PG version which lead to some really awkward dialogue that didn't seem to fit in with the tone of the story. It felt like *lewd comment that leads to H scene* > *scene missing* > *comment about said H scene*.

EDIT: I have since been informed that the Steam version and PLUS + MOSAIC versions dialogue are exactly the same and that the H scenes are part of the extras. I guess in that case I have to call into question the writing, given how really out of place some of the diakogue is. /EDIT

I can't fault the art, music and voice acting which is actually quite good but everything else is very bland. Sadly I feel like this was a waste of time.

19821363.review:
"On this quiet, ending world... I'm experiencing my first and final love."

In general, the opinion of people regarding visual novels is that of disgust due to it's association with it's 18+ counterparts and games like nekopara. (Not that they are necessarily bad games). 

eden* however, is a completely different kind of novel from the differently garbed anime girls throwing themselves at the protagonist's feet in a different interpretation of love. 

The basic premise of eden* is a love story between two very different individuals.

 Right off the bat, from the preview alone, the art, the music, the smooth animation already grabbed my attention.  Believing it to be a truly exceptional work, I wanted a copy of eden* the minute I saw it.

It lived up to my expectations.

Yes, it isn't perfect, the upsize/fullscreen isn't as good, the characters eyes are a little too large for my liking.

But still, in spite of all that, eden* delivers, and what a story it has delivered. The art, the characters, the voice acting, the music, the CGs, the finale and more. Each and every bit of eden* delivers and brings the story to life. To me, the story is not particularly long, at 7-8 hours, yet in game, that time is both fleeting and eternal. At times it feels so excruciatingly long, and at times it passes by so quickly.

And the ending, my sweet merciful (whatever religious figure you believe in or don't for that matter), the ending. Though the read through left me with a sense of melancholy and sorrow at times, at the ending i do not believe it's possible not to shed a few tears.

Words alone cannot convey what a wonderful piece of work eden* is. 

Words alone cannot convey what a touching tale eden* is.

I highly recommend it.

What more need I say

Sweet dreams, Sion.

19406092.review:
*Basic knowledge shown from the beginning of the game is revealed in this review*

8/10: Soundtrack
The soundtrack is nice, but never stands out. It matches with the mood quite well and is never irritating.

11/10 Visuals: A kinetic novel always needs less work, however, the opening and the animated visuals with multi CGs are still fantastic. The amount of CGs make me forget that they're even considered CGs because it feels like it blends in with the story so well along with its frequency. Their mouths move and they blink in every single scene. That is absolutely amazing effort. The opening looks like an anime. The art is so beautiful and impressive.

10/10 Atmosphere: The writing style, audio and visuals were put together to create such an amazing atmosphere. It may be just a kinetic novel, but the way this visual novel was made creates such an amazing atmosphere. When they were in the mountains, I felt ultimately relaxed, but when they were in the facility, I felt more tense. This adds to the feeling of the reader to emphasize with those who stayed in the mansion for so long.

9/10 Plot: Almost a masterpiece! The plot is quite sensical, however only a few small things were never explained. The small things unexplained were not the main point of the plot, so know not to worry. A majority of the plot was explained. The plot is quite sensible and consistent. When I expected the plot to end, it wasn't even close to the end, in fact they covered a majority of plot holes. The plot went about excitingly or gently, never rushed. 


9/10 Characters: The character development was magnificent and each character has more to them than just their looks. Every character shows their stupidity and smarts in different subjects. Their intelligence is also consistent, as well as their personality. Every small thing said shows each character's personality. Each character has a voice actor. They all have clear and voices that match the tone of the scene. Their emotions are easily felt with each character's feelings. By the end, every single character has their endings explained.

9.5/10 Overall: Needless to say, amazing work.

19258682.review:
If every single day in the world could be your last, how would you choose to spend it?

eden*: They were only two, on the planet. is a fully-voiced kinetic visual novel (meaning there are no branching paths) developed by minori and published by MangaGamer. eden* explores the story of Ryou Haruna, a young killing machine that ranks as one of the best soldiers on the force, on his new assignment in a quiet island. Wondering why this settlement would need so much protection, he soon discovers that it is the home and workplace of a girl named Sion, who is hard at work developing ways for the people around the world to leave Earth before an unknown calamity.

Right off the bat, I’ll have to praise the game for its incredible pacing, writing and voice acting. Not once did I ever feel bored while reading through eden*. Each scene only lasts a few short minutes so you’re never forced to go through a large chunk of it at a time, but at the same time the writing is so good that you’re always wondering what happens next.

The kinetic style of eden* doesn’t hamper the story it tells. It perfectly complements the story by providing you with great illustrations and emotional music that really makes you feel every scene. The world is well-built, the graphics are beautiful, the characters are engaging and the voice acting is top-notch.

It’s very difficult to review a kinetic visual novel without spoiling anything important. I will tell you, however, that I was hooked basically from the very first scene, and more than a few tears will be shed by the end.

I highly recommend this game for fans of great stories. I also recommend you to not look at how much the game takes to complete to really feel that every day could be your last.

What I played: The full story arc in under [spoiler]8[/spoiler] hours (I'm a fast reader).
Like: Basically everything.
Dislike: Basically nothing.
Rating: 5 teardrops out of 5

18864651.review:
I have pre-ordered this game a long time ago and actually haven't touched it for a while, having forgotten about it after a while.. One day, my internet was fucked, so I was desperately searching for some kind of source for entertainment and spotted this game on my desktop, which made me think - "Oh, this game, I completely forgot about it!". The first couple of hours into the game, I was constantly wondering how this story was going to expand from here, because for me, the ending was spoiled, due to the nature of the description given to this game. This, I thought, might make the whole VN underwhelming, but I was completely wrong. The overall shell of this VN is easy to figure out, in the early stages of this VN I couldn't help but be sceptical overall about this. The whole trailer type video shown in this page is also a big spoiler for me, as it shows the two main characters already in the mellow state. I couldn't stop wondering about how these two main characters, both seemingly cold-blooded with no humane emotions to be seen, were going to develop. This VN starts off in an oddly relaxing manner, it feels like this game's just going around in circles with its story at times, but after having finished this game, I can't help but appreciate the amount of time I was given to get attached to the characters (deeply, deeply attached). The pacing is incredible, looking back at how the whole entire story has unfolded, in a slow, majestic manner. This game knows to take its time with the story. This game seems to have all the time in the world, contrary to the inhabitants of this small world, the measly human race, desperately struggling to survive the end of the world. Things seem uneventful, duty for the main male protagonist also lacking any kind of action. The seemingly static storyline put me off at first, but as I've mentioned before, this is crucial for this story to have any kind of impact on your feelings, so bear with me on this and this game will show you its worth in full display. Something which has caught my attention very early on into this game is - the incredible dialogue between characters, it's seemingly flawless and the usage/timings of specific words are impeccable, they were incredibly poetic and have made me quite envious of the writer! The way this story develops is simply amazing, I couldn't expect when or how this story would expand, due to the nature of this VN, only sloooowly..and slooooowly.. revealing each and every part of the story, completely trapping me in the game, unable to stop pressing the space bar! I was so absorbed into this game, I had forgotten that it has become midnight, I had forgotten to breathe regularly and ended up having to do it manually! (I guess that's what you call "breathtaking"?) Once the story had started to gain momentum in the storytelling aspect, it has gotten too interesting for me to let go of and time was seemingly flying! (though my clock says otherwise) The main female (Sion) protagonist's character development is astonishing, I knew something had to happen in her for this to be the "Earth's last love story", same goes for the male protagonist. And I was correct, something DID happen (what a surprise). The game had become a feels trip, I cried so many times and so much that I've lost count. "I have become too attached for my own good.." is what I was mumbling, while wiping my tears. *sniff* Yes, if you're wondering about the art and all the other things in this masterpiece, you won't be disappointed, though I expect you've already seen this game's trailers and what not, the art just gets better and better, same with the soundtracks, so you won't need to worry about these aspects being a potential sacrifice in order for them to have created the incredibly immersive and simply touching story. Sion's VA is incredible, she has simply pummelled my heart constantly, with her flawlessly delivered, impactful lines. So I have looked her up on the internet, only to find that she doesn't seem to be well-known at all and by that I mean - she hasn't been a part of many games/anime/vns so on so forth and it's very saddening for me, as I was ready to watch/read what other great things she might have had in store. This is the first game to make me feel my heart wrench, I have actually felt the pain in my chest and the inability to calm myself down from the sadness during and after. The ending of this game has left me in a dazzled state. As the credits were rolling, I was simply staring up ,while lying on my chair, thinking about nothing, absolutely nothing, as this game has left me speechless, accompanied by the feeling of emptiness. 

I give this game 10/10 with no doubt, this deserves more than just a glimpse. Delve into it, experience true melancholy and a feeling of amazement, followed by the feeling of accomplishment after having finished this game, which is truly worth your time.

18656073.review:
Vor einer Zeit schon hat MangaGamer die Visual Novel eden* von minori auf englischer Sprache auf Steam und ihrer eigenen Platform veröffentlicht. Ich habe eden* schon kurz nach dem englischen Release gelesen, bin bisher aber nicht dazu gekommen eine Review darüber zu schreiben. Nun ist es aber Zeit, dies nachzuholen.

    [quote]Titel: eden*
    Entwickler: minori
    Genre:Sci-Fi, Drama
    Länge: ~10h
    Premiere: 18.09.2009 (japanisch), 30.01.2015 (englisch)

    Story:
    In the near future, an ominous red star suddenly appears in the sky. Its presence is about to bring about the extinction of all life on Earth. The unified government proposes an evacuation project to take all of mankind into space, but in order to make the seemingly impossible project a reality, ‚felixes‘ are brought into the world. Engineered to be highly intelligent with perpetual youth and longevity, the genetically modified superhuman felixes stand as humanity’s only hope for survival.

    Sion, the most gifted of the felixes, has been kept in a research facility built on a solitary island for the past hundred years. Her sole purpose, saving all of humanity. Ryou Haruna, a soldier from the Earth’s unified government is sent to watch over Sion, who desperately seeks freedom from the military that’s imprisoning her. Earth’s last love story is about to begin.[/quote]

[h1]Handlung:[/h1]

eden* spielt in einer Welt, in der die Menschen dem Untergang geweiht sind. Die einzige Chance ist, dem Planeten zu entkommen. Hierfür wurden genetisch manipulierte Menschen erschaffen, welche über erhöhte Intelligenz verfügen und genutzt werden um fortschrittliche Raumschiffe zu erschaffen um die Menschheit ins All zu retten. Hierbei verfolgen wir allerdings nicht den Entwicklungsprozess, sondern das Schicksal einer dieser genetisch veränderten Mädchen und von ihrem neu zugeordneten Leibwächter.

Das Setting hat mir recht gut gefallen und auch die Entwicklung der Geschichte ist gut gestaltet. Je weiter es sich allerdings entwickelt, desto mehr liegt der Fokus auf den Charakteren und nicht mehr so stark auf das nahende Ende der Menschheit. Dies hängt aber doch im Hintergrund über allem, was die Charaktere tun. Die ganze Zukunftsvision wirkt durchdacht und hat einen interessanten Ansatz.

Zum Ende hin hatte ich aber ein bisschen das Gefühl, als wenn der Fokus nun zwangsweise extrem auf Drama geschoben werden musste. Auch die Einführung eines weiteren Charakters hat für mich die Story nicht positiv voran gebracht. Zwar sorgt der Charakter dafür, dass es zu einer Entwicklung zwischen den beiden Hauptcharakteren kommt, aber dies wäre auch (angenehmer) ohne diesen möglich gewesen.

Zwischendurch gibt es ein paar Passagen in der Geschichte, in der manche Dinge zu lange und zu breit erklärt werden und dies sogar zu einem späteren Zeitpunkt noch einmal wiederholt wird. Gefühlt ziehen sich diese Stellen elendig in die Länge und bringt die Freude an der Handlung dort ein bisschen ins Stocken.

Da es sich bei eden* um eine Kinetic Novel handelt, gibt es in der Novel selber keine Entscheidungen zu treffen. Hier läuft alles linear ab. Dies ist allerdings nicht als Nachteil zu werten, sondern nur eine andere Darstellungsform.

[h1]Illustrationen:[/h1]

Die Illustrationen in eden* haben mir sehr gut gefallen. Hier gibt es nicht wie bei anderen Visual Novels Charaktersprites, sondern nur die CGs. Daher arbeitet eden* sehr großzügig mit diesen und liefert dem entsprechend für alle wichtigen Szenen auch passende CGs. Die Illustrationen sind schön gestaltet und auch die Charaktere sehen alle gut aus. Vor allem wenn die Landschaft dargestellt wird, hat mir dies gut gefallen.

[h1]Charaktere:[/h1]

Die Charaktere haben mir in eden* alle recht gut gefallen. Es gibt hier nun keinen Charakter, der mir irgendwie unangenehm aufgefallen ist. Auch wenn der Charakter, welcher zum Ende hin neu hinzu kommt, mich in der Story eher stört, so war er doch sympathisch. Letztendlich liegt der Fokus hier aber doch auf den beiden Hauptcharakteren. Hier gefällt mir zum einen das Charakterdesign und die Persönlichkeiten. Vor allem Sion hebt sich hier positiv hervor. Letztendlich ist aber vor allem die Entwicklung, die die beiden Charaktere durch machen das, was sie wirklich interessant macht.

[h1]Sound:[/h1]

Der Sound ist auch hier mal wieder so eine Sache. Die Musik passte gut zu den Szenen und hier wurde eigentlich alles richtig in Szene gesetzt. Allerdings ist bei der Musik nun nichts bei, was besonders hervor sticht und einem im Gedächtnis bleibt. Es ist gute Untermalung der Handlung, mehr allerdings auch nicht.

[h1]Fazit:[/h1]

Und zu Fazit, also die tl;dr Edition von dem, was bereits hier drüber steht. Mir persönlich hat eden* Spaß gemacht zu lesen. Es war eine gute Mischung aus Charakteren und Story mit ansehnlichen Illustrationen. Davon einmal abgesehen war es aber nun auch nichts, was einen überwältigt oder einem furchtbar lange im Gedächtnis bleibt. Das mit dem Review dazu hat auch einfach nur so lange gedauert, weil ich die Novel schlicht weg wieder vergessen habe. Solange wie man es liest unterhält es einen gut, trotz ein paar Passgen die sich einfach nur hinziehen. Sobald man allerdings mit eden* durch ist, verschwindet es doch wieder recht schnell aus dem Gedächtnis.

[h1]7/10[/h1]

18404750.review:
A powerful story about love, life and what it means to live. The story involves the final days of the planet Earth which may seem like a cheap way to inject drama but, honestly, that part of the story may as well be an aside. The fact is that the main story is between our two main characters and it could have just as well been told in another setting while still remaining as powerful. It's very well written with one caveat...

The pacing for the first half is incredibly slow. If you're not a patient person, you may have trouble dragging yourself through it. Speed reading or skimming along until the main characters get together wouldn't be a terrible idea if you feel yourself getting disinterested because there is a great ending to this story, despite the slow start. This is a long story and they get together at about the midway point so you won't be robbing yourself of much by skimming a bit. Lastly, just an FYI, this is a kinetic novel meaning there are no choices, branching paths or interactions. 

As far as the artwork goes, it's mostly top-notch. The characters are often incorporated into the backgrounds instead of the standard VN format of having a background layer with static "pop-up" characters in front of it. There are a few frames of Major Inaba that are comically bad and I question how they ended up in the game when the rest is so well drawn but aside from that, it's all very beautiful.

In summary, it's a great story if you have the time (and a little patience) to put into it. A bit slow to start but it has a fairly powerful finish. I recommend it.

So I can speak for at least how good the story and audio for both are because according to mangagamer.com the only differences between the AO version and the All Ages version is the addult content which are 4 non canon side story, 1 partial nudity scene, showing blood and enhanced CGs and thats  all the  main story is the same in both. So anyway I'll start with saying the main story for eden* is very well done it's got some sad moment, some touching moments, some funny moments and some exciting moments, you won't find any adult scenes in the main story for either the all ages version or the adult version, to get to the adult content you have to finish the main story at least once all the to the end. How ever the story is very detailed and well written so it's well worth the read. The main story didn't make me cry like it did for some other people evidently but I can understand as to why it would. The 4 adult side stories however aren't bad but they aren't great either if I had to rate the main story I'd give it a 10/10 now if I had to rate the 4 side stories I'd suppose if I felt generous I'd give them a 8/10. The Art and animation for both the main and 4 adult side stories were absolutely beautiful, and both the BGM and voice acting were very good. though if I could change 1 thing about the adult side stories it'd be the mosaic's I'd make it uncensored mostly because I think censoring ruins good artwork, without the mosaics the side stories might've gotten a 9/10.  Why only a 9/10 and not a 10/10 well the main story set the bar up to high, I've read hentai manga that've been able to have a good and long story and still add in adult scenes to the story. Hell a parody doujin of Neon Genesis called Re-Take is a  hentai manga with a long story but manages to add in the hentai scenes in a way that they add to the story's quality like there not there just for masterbation. So I think  the developers at minori could've done a better job with the story part of the 4 side stories but chose not to, the side stories are still good just not as good as they could've been. Anyway I'd give both the artwork and animation for the main story a 10/10 the 1st video/movie scene in the main story is amazingly well done just loved the way they did that, and the ending credits just as good as the 1st video/movie. The Audio both the BGM and the voice acting were excellently done in my opinion. Now the artwork and animation in the 4 adult side stories were just as good save for the mosaic's, and the audio once again same as the main really well done. Now is buying eden* Plus+Mosaic worth the extra money I'd say yes I think the added blood and the partial nudity scene enhance the story, now is it worth buying for the 4 adult side stories   I'd say yes plus when you buy eden* Plus+Mosaic from mangagamer.com you get both the adult copy  and a steam key for the all ages version, I'd rate the eden*/eden* Plus+Mosaic a overall of 10/10 so this iss worth every penny in my opinion. I've actually spent at least probably around 60+ hours enjoying this VN as of the writing this review.

18101998.review:
剧情类游戏向来不爱以游戏性作为主要评价代表，把游戏当作一部作品的话，也会有很多要传递的东西。
故事可以看成圣经中所说从亚当夏娃到生下的该隐再到其后裔诺亚造方舟的故事的反过来看。作画CG简直不能再良心，CV也可圈可点。

每日生活在各种琐事、学业、工作之中度过，一直坐在教室里家里办公室里的我们可否也像诗音一样，不曾领略外界的美好。网络的世界日益缤纷多彩，大多时间着眼于美好的现实又有多少人呢。这种不可逆的变化悄然贯穿着我们的生活，你是否已经发觉并想有所改变、像诗音一样重新奔向世界本来的面貌呢？。。可能很多人玩的时候跟我一样有这种想法，游戏时间一过，我们又要投入到社会的大潮当中，与以前并无他样。

所以，珍惜难得游戏时间吧，不要只顾着PM线的发泄欲望，让自己的思想与诗音一起走向那个美好绮丽的湖畔和小丘，得到一丝带有慰藉的幸福。

最后——晚安，诗音。

18081440.review:
[h1][b][i]"How can you live in the present if you are afraid of the end?"[/i][/b][/h1]

If you knew the world would come to its end, how would you spend your remaining time on Earth? If you are Haruna Ryou, you take this opportunity so that you can live the last happy life on this dying planet. 

NOTE: This is a slow paced visual novel. There are only a few jokes here and there to lighten the mood sometimes. Otherwise, this VN can take 10+ hours to read, so if you don't have the patience and you just want to finish a story quickly, this VN probably isn't for you.

[h1]What type of VN is this?[/h1]
This is a kinetic VN, meaning that you read it as if it were a story book. There are no choices to make so just sit back and enjoy the story (and keep tapping the space bar to move to the next line of text if you don't have Auto forward turned on).

[h1]Story:[/h1]
To put it short: The world is coming to an end. People are preparing to evacuate from Earth. Creatures know as Felixes have helped humanity with the evacuation, including one particular Felix, Sion. 
Warrant Officer Ryou is a deadly soldier who struggles to find the reason why he wants to fight and what his goals in life are. He is assigned with a comrade named Lavie by his lieutenant to protect Sion.

The story is told in flashbacks. The story begins with the present, with Ryou and Sion living together. Afterwards, we go back in time and see how things came to be.

[h1]Visuals:[/h1]
There is a reason why Minori's name is on this VN. The scenes are very well done. They are simply, yet beautiful. Character designs are nice. While the building interiors may look generic, there is usually that light streak that helps add some "life" to the scenes. Characters will also blink (it's not much, but its at least better than looking at a still , unmoving picture).

[h1]Sound:[/h1]
Maybe I love the Opening them for eden too much. The soundtrack consists of soft piano music in the background that helps accompany certain scenes. When dramatic scenes start to roll in, you will feel it.
The voice acting for this VN is superb. None of the dialogue feels rushed and it feels as if the characters are having a real conversation as they usually would. When things get serious, you will definitely hear it coming.


[h1]Should you buy it?[/h1]
Like I said before, it's best to enjoy eden if you have the patience for this story. This story can be considered a love story".

18025366.review:
PROS:
- The premise is good. 
- Animated blinking and mouth movements matched to dialogue.
- Nice music and voice acting.
- The writing style is vivid.

CON:
- The story

I had high expectations when I saw that this VN had high ratings in Steam but was rather disappointed.  My first impression was something like "Kazami Yuuji meets Reverie Planetarian" but the end result was a rather weak plot.   Planetarian made me cry like a child and Grisaia made me gasp, but Eden didn't make me shed a single tear.

Comparison with other VNs aside, the story in general was pretty bland. Whatever excitement I got from the "research facility" arc disappeared completely in the arcs that followed. It's like they tried to follow the mirror image of the plot mountain, starting with the climax and ending with exposition. The story became some bland slice-of-life between Gary Stu and Mary Sue. It did a good job tying plot elements together but it all felt unnecessary towards the end, messily resolving any conflict.

It's a well-spent 10+ hour story, a calming ride, a relaxing experience... but it doesn't feel like it's worthy of its high ratings. I'm glad I bought this at a discount - I might've had buyer's remorse if I had bought this at full price.

18009500.review:
[Unfinished]

[Disclaimer] This review contains very minor spoilers. And for those who do not wish to read the entire length of my review, a TL;DR is located at the end of the review summarizing my thoughts.

[Synopsis] Over a hundred years ago, humanity learned of a humungous comet, one massive enough to obliterate Earth itself. Now, as the day of destruction closes in, most of the human race has already evacuated into space in search of a new beginning. This escape is largely due to the accomplishments of a woman named Sion - a genius scientist born as a part of a new race of intellectually-enhanced humans created for the sole purpose to find a method to counteract humanity's extinction. It was at this time that she met Ryo, a soldier seemingly void of life and purpose, who was ordered to become her bodyguard. Now, let the curtains rise on the last love story on earth…

[Review] Eden* is undoubtedly one of the best and most touching VNs currently available on Steam, and is a must buy for anyone looking for a beautifully written and somber story accompanied by fantastic visuals and music. Though there are certainly flaws within the VN itself, I believe the pros far outweight the cons of this VN.

Pros:
• Characters - Each and every one of the characters is written with care. Though each falls into a certain trope in their early stages of development, depth is carefully layered upon each character that far surpasses their original trope.
• Music - Eden* has some of the most pleasantly somber tracks I've heard in any VN. Many classical instruments are used including the violin and the piano.
• Voice Acting - 
• CG/Visuals - 
• Pacing - 
• Translation -

Cons:
• Price - For a 10 to 15 hour VN (varies on whether you choose to use the autoplay feature and/or skip voice acting), $19.99 is a pretty high price. Though I'd love to say it's completely worth it, I'd recommended waiting for it to go on sale. Fortunately for me, I was able to pick Eden* up months after release in a very cheap Humble Bundle deal for less than a dollar.
• Certain Facial Proportions - Eden* has some of the biggest eyes I've seen since CLANNAD, so for some it might be a turn off. Additionally, Ryou has the most awkward looking facial features in many of the CGs he's included in.
• Minor Distracting Fanservice - Though fanservicey shots are used extremely rarely (taking up less than 5 minutes in total screentime), I find it still worth mentioning that there are a few CGs which included some unnecessary fanservicey elements to them.
• User Interface - Compared to other VNs of similar quality, Eden* has a very basic UI.
• Animations - 
• Plus MOSAIC (18+ additional content) - Entirely unnecessary. Unless for some reason you desire the eroge content the game offers separately (only available on MangaGamer), I wouldn't touch this.

TL;DR: A little slow to start, but the tears will rain soon enough.

17965831.review:
[h1]Score: 9/10[/h1]

[b][u]Similar Games[/u][/b]
If My Heart Had Wings, Higurashi When They Cry, narcissu

[b][u]Summary[/u][/b]
The earth is about to be smashed to bits by a red star. Having known this for 100 years a certain someone was instrumental in creating a space program so man could escape. People were not given a choice on if they could stay and die so many were outraged. Some also refused to believe the end would ever come. Thus the world has been in a constant state of martial law style war. The main male character is former special forces and a ruthless killer in his own eyes totally full of sin. Will he and the countless other people he meets find an internal sense of redemption or a way to atone for the immense guilt they feel?

[b][u]Positive[/u][/b]
Well obviously art and sound are top notch for a VN. I mean just watch the preview video. The story has a nice way of coming full circle and telling stories within stories. The whole story itself is by no means short like most VN titles bosting over 10 hours of story. 

[b][u]Negative[/u][/b]
It ends up very difficult for a rational person to find any point in some of the decisions made since there is really no reason things had to turn out so heart wrenching if you think about it after your done with the game. This is a kinetic novel so choices do not exist. It's actually kind of a shame that choices don't exist because the option to make this into a Clannad type visual novel would have made more sense even if the story suffered slightly. In the end this game reminded me a lot of Clannad the anime series because it felt like it was purposely set up for feels even when it didn't make a whole lot of sense.

[b][u]Conclusion[/u][/b]
If you don't mind emotional stories with well developed characters this is a must. So far it is the best VN I've experience on steam easily beating the rest. Unlike many other steam VN's that have hentai on other sites this one has it available on other sites, but it actually is separate and makes little sense with the game if you go that route. Thus the steam version is actually better in my opinion because it won't make you wonder about that other content that makes little sense with the story. Even if I do think the story purposely makes the reader sad by having the characters purposely choose the more painful route even though there were way better options available I still respect it none the less.

[b][u]Value[/u][/b]
I would say about $15. To be honest I usually don't value VN games at a high value so this is actually rather up there for me. Especially since I normally say $1 per hour of gameplay. Except this time the story, sound, and slight animations make it worth the extra $0.50 an hour.

17954936.review:
This kinetic novel follows the point of view of a young man who has seen more combat than he should have. He enters a mysterious facility and meets a girl who has more to her than meets the eye. No, I promise you I have not confused eden* with Planetarian. That said, if you enjoyed Planetarian, then I think you are very likely to enjoy eden*.

The visuals in eden* are good. In addition to having a variety of poses and facial expressions for each character, the characters are shown to blink and their lips sync with the voice acting. There are many CGs and each one is beautiful to see. Several locations even have multiple CGs and this gives the impression of a changing camera angle. I like it.

As eden* is a visual novel, the topic of H-scenes should be raised. I did some research and discovered that the H-scenes are apparently bonus content to unlock in the main menu after completing the kinetic novel once. This means that the H-scenes are not at all relevant to developing the canon storyline. So don’t worry about characters suddenly referring to something that happened during a deleted H-scene. That said, I also read that the H-scenes add more depth to each character despite being non-canon. Anyway, it should be well known now that if you want to see H-scenes then you should buy directly from MangaGamer.

The sound is good. The background music sets the mood well. However, it does not loop well because the end of the music fades to silence before starting again. The voice acting is good. I did not find any characters irritating to listen to. I think the emotions contained in the voice acting were appropriate for each character and the situation.

The story is told using flashbacks, and it makes some of the plot developments easy to see coming. The setting is easy to follow. The plot is decent and enjoyable, but it is not great. The translation is good. There are a few instances when I think a native English speaker would find the text unnatural but the text is still grammatically correct so it can still be understood.

Overall, I enjoyed eden* and recommend it to people who enjoy visual/kinetic novels. It is not a great kinetic novel, but it is good enough to deserve a place in the visual/kinetic novel library.

17898724.review:
Eden* è la storia di un mondo giunto ormai alla sua conclusione e "dell'ultima storia d'amore su quel pianeta chiamato Terra". Una storia destinata anch'essa a finire inevitabilmente.

Come la stragrande maggioranza delle VN presenti su Steam, anche questa è in Giapponese con "sottotitoli" in inglese. Per cui, senza una buona conoscenza della lingua è difficile goderne fino in fondo.
Avverto fin da subito che non si tratta del tipo di Visual Novel dove è possibile effettuare delle scelte (come Fate Stay/Night ad esempio), ma la narrazione scorre su un unico binario, senza finali alternativi o route diverse. L'unica cosa che saremo chiamati a fare è premere il tasto invio per far andare avanti i dialoghi.
Sviluppata dalla compagnia Minori, famosa soprattutto per "Ef: A Fairy Tale of the Two" ("Ef: A Tale of Memories" e "Ef: A Tale of Melodies" per chi ha visto le due serie anime), racconta una drammatica storia d'amore in un mondo ormai al collasso.

La trama di Eden è molto semplice e nemmeno molto originale in fin dei conti, ma funziona piuttosto bene.
Il protagonista, Ryou, è un militare che fin da piccolo ha passato la maggior parte del suo tempo sul campo di battaglia tra un conflitto e l'altro in questo clima di costante guerra civile che accompagna il mondo ormai da molti anni. Si ritrova ad essere assegnato alla protezione di Sion, la famosa creatrice del programma spaziale di evacuazione terrestre necessario alla salvezza dell'umanità. Umanità cui manca ormai poco tempo perché infatti il mondo sta per finire.
In questa struttura di ricerca, farà la conoscenza di Elica, una cameriera che si occupa di Sion, Lavie, un'altra guardia del corpo di Sion, e una vecchia conoscenza di Ryou, il maggiore Inaba.
Senza fare spoiler, gli eventi prenderanno una piega particolare, e porteranno il protagonista a fare una scelta molto importante.

I personaggi non sfuggono ai classici stereotipi tipici delle opere giapponesi, ma fortunatamente gli sviluppatori non hanno troppo calcato la mano su questo frangente.
Il cast non è ampio, cosa che ha sicuramente aiutato nella caratterizzazione dei personaggi, piuttosto profonda.
Sul lato tecnico è perfettamente godibile. I disegni sono molto piacevoli e una nota di merito va ai fondali, davvero ben curati.
Le OST sono in linea con la drammaticità che permea l'opera, ma vi sono anche musiche un po' più frizzanti per le scene di commedia. Inutile dire che è stata data molta più attenzione alla prima categoria, essendo il drama la componente principale dell'opera. C'è da dire che dopo molte ore di gioco iniziano a risultare un po' ripetitive.
Ottimo il doppiaggio, che vanta nomi come Junji Majima, Eriko Nakamura e Mai Goto (ho apprezzato particolarmente quest'ultima)

Una cosa che mi ha fatto storcere un po' il naso è il ritmo della narrazione, a volte davvero molto lento. Vero anche che ciò non è inusuale per una Visual Novel, ma a volte le situazioni risultano un po' troppo ripetitive, dovuto anche all'ambientazione, non molto sviluppata. Se aggiungiamo anche che le ore di gioco sono un bel po' (io ci ho messo 20 ore a finirla, anche se ci sono andato davvero moooolto con calma), si ha a volte la sensazione di non fare progressi di sorta.
Le location della storia saranno infatti principalmente due. Questo costringe i personaggi a interagire tra di loro sempre nel solito clima di staticità che crea un'ambientazione così scarsa. Questa stasi si ripercuote negativamente anche sulle situazioni e le interazioni tra i personaggi, oltre che nel progredire della storia.
In ogni caso la drammaticità, soprattutto a metà e a fine opera riesce a dare diverse emozioni, facendo scoprire allo spettatore di essersi affezionato ai personaggi.

Ultimo punto da definire è la versione +Mosaic.
La versione qui presente su Steam è quella censurata dalle scene di sesso. Infatti, sul sito ufficiale degli sviluppatori è possibile acquistare con un'ulteriore spesa il pacchetto +Mosaic, che trasforma la VN in un vero e proprio Eroge, oltre che migliorare la CG.
Avendo provato solo la versione di Steam non so dire se questa patch aggiunga profondità al gioco (non dovrebbe, a detta degli sviluppatori, aggiungere nulla alla trama). Il problema è che nella versione normale non si fa nemmeno un vago riferimento a nessun rapporto sessuale avvenuto tra il protagonista e uno qualunque dei personaggi femminili (dovrebbe passarsele tutte nel +Mosaic xD) e la mia impressione è che risulterebbe poco realistico, oltre a distruggere l'atmosfera di dolcezza e romanticismo che permea soprattutto le fasi finali dell'opera.
Ma queste sono solo mie supposizioni basate sul nulla.

IN CONCLUSIONE
Eden* è indubbiamente consigliata a chiunque piacciano le opere di matrice giapponese come anime e manga. 
Può piacere sia a chi non si è mai avvicinato ad una Visual novel, sia a chi ne ha già provate altre.
La storia è ben curata, soprattutto il rapporto tra i personaggi essendo il vero punto di forza della VN, dato che in quanto a sviluppo vero e proprio degli eventi, pecca un po' in ripetitività.
Sul lato tecnico è molto godibile sotto ogni punto di vista.

Consigliata!

17894411.review:
[b]"The only way to deal with an unfree world is to become so absolutely free that your very existence is an act of rebellion." ~ Albert Camus[/b]

I haven't been playing visual novels for years now. Around the time that I got involved with adult responsibilities a couple year back, I involuntarily stopped sparing time for the genre. Thanks to a friend's insistent screenshot sharing of many beautiful VNs, I noticed that I've been missing pretty artwork and superficial stories in a very girly manner. I gave up and decided to give the genre a go after a long time. My first pick though, being anything but superficial, left me thoughtful and shaken.

[i]eden*[/i] is a tale of compassion, free will and tomorrow. It is the tale of a world coming to its end. It all started with the appearance of an ominous red star on the sky. After through research, scientists agreed that it is the first warning sign of the end. It took a hundred years for mankind to prepare themselves for a major immigration project to evacuate the planet and search for its destiny elsewhere. During these final moments of the worn planet earth, there are yet things to wonder and chains to break. Between a stoic soldier, a secluded genius, a kind maid, a broken warrior, a regretful commander and a loud journalist; [i]eden*[/i] is the tale of breaking chains.

The game is designed to be a kinetic novel - which means a visual novel without any choice options. You only keep reading and watching the story as it unfolds. In this manner, it cannot wholly be defined as a game. The quality of CGs and the labor put into artwork are far beyond your casual visual novel though. Characters present a full selection of animations, including moving eyes and lip synch with Japanese voice acting. Voice acting is also beyond the par, as if taken out of an A+ anime series. Translation from Japanese to English is great - which is a rare case in any media - and manages to deepen the mood furthermore. The game is quite long so to say; if you'll be waiting for voice acting you can expect an average game time of 13-15 hours.

I'd love to share some character details, but any relevant information about identities or backgrounds would be downright spoilers. Have you ever watched [i]Clannad[/i]? With After Story part of course. If your answer is no, it is a huge recommendation. If yes, you already know what kind of soul wrecking experience that you are getting yourself into. You'll remember Sion and Ryou's story for a long while.

Please also check out Lady Storyteller's Curator page [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/ladystoryteller#curation]here[/url] - follow for regular updates on reviews for other games!

17888913.review:
Upon completing this game, I've never felt more compelled to write a review sharing just WHY this game is a must-buy for any person.  Truly, anybody.  I should mention, no spoilers in this review.  So newcomers, read to your heart's content!  Veterans, enjoy the ride.  :-)

I never believed myself to be the visual novel type person.  Games where you just read text always seemed boring to me.  I usually play more RPG/Adventure type games where you actually DO things with your characters, not where there is a set, linear outcome.  

But this game truly altered my views on visual novels.  

I like to think of my myself as a rather "tough" individual when it comes to watching movies and playing games and not getting genuinely sad or "immersed" with the characters in the story.  Not so with this game.  I can count no less than 3 times when I had tears in my eyes playing this and many many other times when I felt concerned beyond what I can describe for the characters within this game's incredibly well-presented story.  

The story combines science-fiction with romance to create a very interesting situations.  And the use of suspense, oh my God.  The feeling of: "NOOOOOOOO, not now!" or: "That's not good..." will grip you and tear you apart all throughout the story.  It's fantastic.  Truly fantastic and engaging.  

The game's soundtrack is beautiful.  Although at points I have wondered: "Oh boy, that song again?" it does not detract from the game in any way.  Although a few times when it kicked in it scared me, I remedied the issue by turning BGM down just a tad in options.  Then no problems.  

I thought the art style was sort of weird at first, but now it is very appealing to me.  I guess it may be my sister's very awkward views on what is anatomically correct, but I promise this game's art is quite incredible and that my sister is full of crap.

In terms of characters, their development, and how they change over the course of the story, I've never experienced anything quite like this.  Some of the most powerful scenes I've ever seen have come from this game.  I cannot applaud Minori, the creator of this work of art, enough for the beautiful creation I have just witnessed.  This is off the grading scale.  

I'd have to invent an entirely new grading scale to accurately rate how good this game is to me.  But I'll spare those details.

I came, expecting it to be a "crappy harem" with a "strange" art-style and only one, "dry" ending.  Plus ew, all that text you have to read and potentially "bad" voice actors/actresses.  

I left feeling completely different.  Changed.  Soothed, if you will.  Also, I must say my prior judgements are unfathomly incorrect.  If you have any/all of those like I did, play the game.  You will see what I mean after completing the game.  You will be most surprised.

The game has an overwhelmingly positive rating, and I am proud to contribute to that.  As my first ever review for a game, I am most satisfied it is with this glorious visual novel.  I played.  I cried.  I left feeling at peace and satisfied with my purchase.  Money well spent.

TLDR:
Recommended.  :-)  Very highly recommended.  :-) :-) :-)

PS- And don't rush through it, whatever you do (I didn't, although towards the end I was quite anxious to see the ending, although I never skipped anything).  Enjoy it.  And remember, do not suppress your tears.  Or I probably would've cried a ton more, and especially audibly at no less than 3 parts in the game.  Part of enjoying games like these are to truly take in their beauty and let your emotion express itself, as it should be allowed to.

17884391.review:
First of all i'll start by saying, This is gonna be kind of a long review (might be my actual first serious review to anything actually)
This novel made me laugh and then cry. ;c

This is the story of the end of the world and the woman who saved humanity.

One day, humanity learned the Earth was doomed—that an interplanetary object would collide with our planet, destroying its capability to support life. Humanity would have only 100 years to escape the planet and venture out into the stars.

To accomplish this monumental task, one scientist genetically engineered genius children. Among these was Sion, the genius among geniuses who would go on to design the ships and engines to make interstellar travel into a reality. And now, as Earth enters its last days and mankind has begun its migration to the heavens, she has but one wish: freedom.

I highly recommend Eden* to those who love romantic visual novels, but mostly to those who have the patience! Not only is the story rather long, but some scenes seem drawn out more than they should be. At the same time, there’s plenty of character development. If you’re someone who wants a story told with little backstory or diversions, this game is not for you. Those who can stick it out, definitely pick this game up! The music should also keep you entranced while reading all the dialogue.


This game was so worth the money and time, you should try it out too ^-^

17879810.review:
Отличный сюжет. Интересная история. Красивейшие арты. Найлучшее музыкальное сопровождение.
Все это объеденяет "eden*".
Прошел большое кол-во визуальных новелл и был приятно удивлен данной игрой.
Необычый сюжет данной новеллы привлекает с первых минут игры,а сама картинка и музыка имеющиеся в этой новелле разжигает к ней неподдельный интерес.
Новелла полностью линейна,то есть,вы никак не будете влиять или как-то участвовать в развитии истории.
(От вас только требуется жать кнопку для смены реплик:D и конечно же наслаждаться сюжетом.)
Об игре:
Будущие.Рядом с Марсом появляется неизвестный сгусток энергии,под влияние которого попадает наша с вам любимая планета Земля.
Большое кол-во природных катаклизмов,изменение климата - все это пагубно начало влиять на планету и ей остается всего навсего 100 лет жизни.
Ну а что люди?А люди нашли выход - готовиться покинуть планету и попутно изобрести технологию,позволяющию людям жить в открытом космосе.
Первые испытания.Появление генномодифицированнных людей.Получив успехи в области генной инженерии,человечество начинает готовиться к эвакуации.
Вот тут то мы и вступаем в дело.Вы - успешный солдат,которому дают задание защищать девушку(одну из генномодифицированных людей).
И как только они повстречают друг друга - начнется увлекательная,романтическая история двоих возлюбленных на умирающей планете.
Оценка:
Просто 10/10.Без шуток и прочего.Серьезная новелла с глубоким сюжетом.Нечасто встретишь такой продукт и ставить его на ровне с какими-нибудь жалкими новеллками просто бессмысленно.
